Italy's parties enthuse over Draghi after talks to form government
Italy's political parties on the left and right enthused at the prospect of backing a Mario Draghi government after meeting the prime minister-designate today as he wrapped up his second round of consultations. Draghi is expected to report back to Italy's head of state and propose his list of cabinet ministers by tomorrow, political sources said. By then he will know whether he has the backing of the largest party in parliament, the anti-establishment 5-Star Movement, which is holding an online ballot of its members over the next two days to decide its stance.

There is an excellent summary of the situation in the following article, which includes four scenarios - worthwhile introductory reading: https://www.thelocal.it/20210126/explained-why-has-italy-prime-minister-resigned-and-what-happens-now Essentially those four scenarios:
(1) a new Conte led-coalition. For this Conte would need to win back the support of Renzi's party. While this appears likely as it is the simplest resolution, the fact remains that Renzi left after some time of pushing for a solution. Even if it was needed to show he was serious, it does show how difficult those negotiations would be. Renzi would need to be given a change in policy by Conte or some other powers. 50%
(2) Conte is replaced by another individual able to win the support of Italia Viva. This is less likely as it would require a figure that has the support of both of the two main coalition partners. That would be difficult and take time. 25%
(3) An entirely new government which may win the support of a different coalition (including the centre-right). If neither of the above two solutions are achieved, then the coalition may fall apart and new alliances could be formed. 20%
(4) elections are called by the President. The chances of elections are low, as even Salvini and Lega Norda may not benefit. The number of seats in the new upper and lower houses will also be far smaller. The last early elections in 2008, 1996, and 1994 following the breakdown of coalitions took place under very different circumstances, but they do show the chances are not 0. So I would estimate 5%. In all of those scenarios, Conte stays in power only in one, The % chances are unscientific but I have been unable to find easily accessible relevant statistics (global or European stats for coalitions reforming following the resignation of the PM,)

(https://www.cnn.com/2021/01/26/europe/italy-giuseppe-conte-resignation-intl/index.html) There is not a clear person to succeed Conte since they would struggle to form a majority coalition.
